headline.main: THREE WHO HAVE CHOSEN A LIFE IN THE WILD

results.snippet: From the time all three were little girls, they wanted to be out in the wilderness, alone with their animals. They have now spent many years in the remotest corners of Africa and Asia, enduring isolation, torrential rains, heat, insects and, in the...

byline.original: By NAN ROBERTSON, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: From the time all three were little girls, they wanted to be out in the wilderness, alone with their animals. They have now spent many years in the remotest corners of Africa and Asia, enduring isolation, torrential rains, heat, insects and, in the cases of two of them, long separations from their sons, who were thousands of miles away in England and British Columbia. This week Dian Fossey, Jane Goodall and Birute Galdikas came together in a rare meeting to talk about ''What We Can Learn About Humankind From the Apes'' at a symposium on the Sweet Briar College campus, which was drenched in the white dogwood and azalea of a Southern spring. 'You're My Idol' They have become three of the world's foremost primatologists, those who study the great apes, with Dr. Fossey specializing in mountain gorillas, Dr. Goodall in chimpanzees and Dr. Galdikas in orangutans. Their lectures and slides appeared to enthrall the anthropologists, sociologists, zoologists, alumnae, students and those just curious to see three women who are fast becoming legends in their field. ''Jane Goodall,'' one young man said solemnly, ''you're my idol.''

headline.main: Russian and Rumanian Are Launched Into Orbit

results.snippet: A Rumanian astronaut and his Soviet commander were launched into space today aboard a Soyuz 40 spacecraft, Tass, the official press agency, announced.   Dumitru Prunariu, a 28-year-old senior lieutenant in the Rumanian Air Force, and Lieut Col....
results.lead_paragraph: A Rumanian astronaut and his Soviet commander were launched into space today aboard a Soyuz 40 spacecraft, Tass, the official press agency, announced. Dumitru Prunariu, a 28-year-old senior lieutenant in the Rumanian Air Force, and Lieut Col. Leonid Popov, 36, of the Soviet Air Force, were reported to be in good condition after the launching at 1:17 P.M., New York time.

headline.main: Rumanian Said to Dock With Soviet Spacecraft

results.snippet: The first Rumanian astronaut, accompanied by a Soviet veteran, docked a Soyuz 40 space capsule today with an orbiting space station manned by two other astronauts, Western official observers reported today.   The linking of the Soyuz and the Salyut...
results.lead_paragraph: The first Rumanian astronaut, accompanied by a Soviet veteran, docked a Soyuz 40 space capsule today with an orbiting space station manned by two other astronauts, Western official observers reported today. The linking of the Soyuz and the Salyut 6 space station took place sometime between 11:30 P.M. and 12:30 A.M., the observers said.

results.snippet: Legendary American heroes of space travel - Shepard, Glenn, Armstrong, Aldrin, Borman - and 35 other astronauts joined President Reagan today in a salute to the crew of the space shuttle Columbia and their ''victory for the American spirit.''  ...
results.lead_paragraph: Legendary American heroes of space travel - Shepard, Glenn, Armstrong, Aldrin, Borman - and 35 other astronauts joined President Reagan today in a salute to the crew of the space shuttle Columbia and their ''victory for the American spirit.'' ''John Young and Bob Crippen have made us very proud,'' President Reagan declared in an Oval Office ceremony. ''Their deeds reminded us that we as a free people can accomplish whatever we set out to do. Nothing binds our abilities except our expectations, and, given that, the farthest star is within our reach.''

headline.main: Soviet and Rumanian Astronauts Return After a Week of Orbiting

results.snippet: A Soviet astronaut and a Rumanian astronaut returned to earth today after a week in orbit aboard the Soviet space station Salyut 6, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported.
results.lead_paragraph: A Soviet astronaut and a Rumanian astronaut returned to earth today after a week in orbit aboard the Soviet space station Salyut 6, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported.

results.snippet: Almost two years ago, a pylon and engine ripped from the underwing of a DC-10 as it lifted off the runway of Chicago's O'Hare Airport.  The resulting accident took the lives of 273 men, women and children. The plane was grounded for 38 days. The...
results.lead_paragraph: Almost two years ago, a pylon and engine ripped from the underwing of a DC-10 as it lifted off the runway of Chicago's O'Hare Airport. The resulting accident took the lives of 273 men, women and children. The plane was grounded for 38 days. The McDonnell Douglas Corporation estimated that 10 percent of the public avoided DC-10's after the plane resumed operation. ''It still hurts to talk about it,'' said James Burton, director of marketing for McDonnell Douglas, maker of the DC-10. While passenger fear could be soothed with time and a media blitz featuring Pete Conrad, the former astronaut, vouching for the company's superior technology, the commercial aircraft business at McDonnell Douglas is still burdened with the legacy of May 25, 1979.

results.snippet: Two Soviet astronauts piloted their Soyuz-T 4 spacecraft to a soft landing in Central Asia yesterday for the successful conclusion of the final mission to the Earth-orbiting Salyut 6 space station, which for nearly four years has been the sturdy...
results.lead_paragraph: Two Soviet astronauts piloted their Soyuz-T 4 spacecraft to a soft landing in Central Asia yesterday for the successful conclusion of the final mission to the Earth-orbiting Salyut 6 space station, which for nearly four years has been the sturdy base for record-setting tests of human endurance and the centerpiece of the Russian space program. Even though the Soviet Union has not said so officially, another space station is expected to replace the 21-ton cylindrical Salyut 6, which is about the size of a small mobile home. According to American analysts of the Soviet program, the new vehicle could be more complex and capable of being enlarged through attached modules. 4 Test Flights Successful Further evidence that the Russians may have reached a transition point in their space program was a statement made last week by a Soviet astronaut, Leonid Popov, that there would be no more flights with the old-model Soyuz spacecraft.

headline.main: SOVIET SUSPENDS MANNED FLIGHTS AS SPACE PRIORITIES ARE CHANGED

results.snippet: Soviet space officials said yesterday that they planned no more manned flights for several months at least, and perhaps a year, but that they would keep the Salyut 6 space station orbiting the earth for use in unmanned scientific and technical...
results.lead_paragraph: Soviet space officials said yesterday that they planned no more manned flights for several months at least, and perhaps a year, but that they would keep the Salyut 6 space station orbiting the earth for use in unmanned scientific and technical experiments. The announcement provided a further indication that the Russians are entering a transition period in their space program, moving from an emphasis on learning man's capacity to live and work in space toward, perhaps, a period of expanding the space facilities for that work. The Salyut 6 had been occupied by crews almost continuously ever since it was placed in orbit in 1977.

headline.main: WHAT I'M WRITING, WHAT I'M READING

results.snippet: The Book Review asked a number of authors what they planned to write and read this summer.   Eve Babitz, Author of ''Eve's Hollywood,'' ''Slow Days, Fast Company'' and ''Sex and Rage.''   This summer I plan to finish the novel I planned to finish...
results.lead_paragraph: The Book Review asked a number of authors what they planned to write and read this summer. Eve Babitz, Author of ''Eve's Hollywood,'' ''Slow Days, Fast Company'' and ''Sex and Rage.'' This summer I plan to finish the novel I planned to finish last summer, and last winter, and this spring. It's supposed to be out this year, and if it isn't, I can always go back to writing short stories. Of course, anyone who only publishes short stories is thought to be a ''slender talent'' (and not in a nice way). But you can't convince people you're fat by writing just one novel - you've got to write two before you can publish short stories again, or they'll say you're ''burnt out.''
